subject: Dear Charles
body:
Dear Friend,

This is to acknowledge the receipt of your email.

The total fund is One Hundred Forty-Nine Million Three Hundred Fifty-One
Thousand Eighty-Seven cents ($149,351,000.00).

As soon as I have submitted the necessary documents I will demand proof of
funds from the management of the bank.

As you have known that you are purporting to be the next of kin to my late
client late Robert 'Roy’ Watterson who died in a plane crash in Australia.

He had funds deposited with a commercial bank he wanted to invest in
telecommunication and only I and his work colleague that died with him are
aware of the fund and the investment.

I contacted you to assist in repatriating the money that belonged to my
client before it was declared serviceable by the bank management here in
Ireland where the fund was lodged. I am assuring you that the transaction
is 100% risk-free only if you adhere to my instruction.


I agreed to share the funds 50/45, the 5% for the expenses that each party
will incurred in this DEAL and  since I can't succeed without your
assistance I have to offer the percentage.

In dealing with a deceased person’s money and property the following have
to be put in place which I have done with your consent to bring the
traction to this stage.
Let me explain in detail the process of administering a deceased person's
Fund in Ireland.

If there is a WILL and an executor has been appointed, then the executor
deals with the Fund. This means that they make sure that the spouse/civil
partner is aware of the legal right to share and distribute the Fund in
accordance with the will and the law.

If there is no WILL, or, if there is a WILL but there is no executor, an
administrator is appointed - usually the next of kin or a solicitor.

In order to get authority to administer the fund, you must get a legal
document called a Grant of Representation. This is a legal order that gives
you the authority to administer (probate office) and register the deceased
person's fund.

My dear friend and dedicated partner kindly send a copy of your
international passport and proof of address and private telephone.

Take your time to study all the documents I attached, fill and sign the
ones you have and return. The Personal application form you should go to
section C and provide the information from c1 to c5 only.

On receiving the requested information, I will use it to secure Probate and
Letters of Administration from the Probate Office and the District Probate
Registry.

You will be known as the legal next of kin to my late client immediately
the documents have been secured.

I will file a letter of claim on your behalf to the bank with an affidavit,
Probate and Letters of Administration.

Thank you once again for your willingness to assist, and I look forward to
hearing from you.

Find the attached copy of my documents for your personal peruse.

Remember always to keep our discussion secret and confidential at all times.

Wassalam.

Moatmad Khaled Faraj Mansour.
+353 8994 92558

subject: Re: Dear Charles
body:
Dear Moatmad Khaled Faraj Mansour,

Thank you for reaching out to me and providing all this information. I must admit, it's quite overwhelming, but I'm willing to learn more about the process you mentioned regarding the deceased person's fund in Ireland.

Could you please explain to me what exactly is a Grant of Probate and Letters of Administration? How do these documents give someone the authority to administer the deceased person's fund?

Also, I noticed that you mentioned sharing the funds for expenses incurred in this deal. Could you please clarify what expenses would be involved and how they would be shared?

I appreciate your patience in answering my questions. Looking forward to hearing from you soon.

Best wishes,
Charles

subject: Dear Charles
body:
Charles, Certainly! A Grant of Probate and Letters of Administration are
legal documents issued by a court that deal with the administration of a
deceased person’s estate. Here’s a breakdown of each:

1. Grant of Probate: This document is issued when a deceased person has
left a valid will, and the named executor(s) in the will are seeking
permission from the court to administer the estate. The Grant of Probate
confirms the executor’s authority to handle the deceased person’s assets,
debts, and distribute the estate according to the instructions outlined in
the will. It is essentially a legal recognition that the will is valid and
the executor has the right to act on behalf of the deceased.
2. Letters of Administration: On the other hand, Letters of Administration
are issued when a person dies without leaving a valid will (intestate) or
if the named executor(s) in the will are unable or unwilling to act. In
such cases, the court grants Letters of Administration to an appropriate
individual, usually a close family member, who becomes the administrator of
the estate. The Letters of Administration authorize the administrator to
handle the deceased person’s assets, debts, and distribute the estate
according to the legal rules of intestacy (the laws that determine how
assets are distributed when there is no will).

In both cases, obtaining a Grant of Probate or Letters of Administration is
a formal process that involves submitting the necessary documents,
including the original will (if applicable), to the probate court. The
court reviews the application, verifies the validity of the will (if
present), and ensures that the appropriate person is granted the authority
to administer the estate.

It’s important to note that the specifics of probate and administration
laws can vary between jurisdictions, so it’s advisable to consult with a
legal professional or seek guidance from the relevant court in your area
for accurate and detailed information.

The expenses involved in obtaining a Grant of Probate or Letters of
Administration.  Here are some the breakdown:

1. Court Fees: Most jurisdictions require the payment of court fees when
applying for a Grant of Probate or Letters of Administration. The fees can
vary significantly, so it’s important to check with the relevant court to
determine the exact amount.

2. Executor/Administrator Fees: The executor or administrator of the estate
is entitled to claim reasonable fees for their services. The specific
amount can vary and is often based on a percentage of the estate’s value or
an hourly rate. The executor’s fees are typically paid from the estate
assets, and the exact amount should be discussed and agreed upon by all
beneficiaries.
4. Valuation Fees: It may be necessary to have the assets of the estate
professionally valued, especially if there are valuable or unique items
involved. Valuation fees can include appraisals of real estate, jewelry,
artwork, or other valuable possessions.
5. Publication Fees: In some jurisdictions, it may be required to publish a
notice of the deceased’s death and the intention to apply for probate or
administration in a local newspaper. Publication fees would be incurred for
this purpose.

It’s important to note that the sharing of expenses can vary depending on
the circumstances and the terms outlined in the will (if applicable).
Generally, the expenses associated with obtaining a Grant of Probate or
Letters of Administration are to be paid by us.

I hope that the details explanation will be of an help.
Regards,
Moatmad

subject: Re: Dear Charles
body:
Hello Moatmad,

Thank you for sharing this information about Grant of Probate and Letters of Administration. I appreciate the breakdown of each document and their purposes. It's interesting to learn about the legal process involved in administering an estate.

I have a few follow-up questions, if you don't mind. Firstly, what are some common reasons why someone might not leave a valid will? And in such cases, who typically becomes the administrator of the estate?

Additionally, could you provide more information on the court fees involved in obtaining Grant of Probate or Letters of Administration? Are these fees fixed or do they vary depending on the size of the estate?

Thank you again for your help!

Best wishes,
Charles

subject: Re: Dear Charles
body:
There can be several reasons why someone might not leave a valid will. Some
common reasons include:

1. Procrastination: Many people simply put off creating a will, assuming
they have plenty of time or believing it is not necessary at their current
stage of life.
2. Lack of awareness: Some individuals may not fully understand the
importance of having a will or the consequences of dying intestate (without
a will).
3. Complexity of family dynamics: Complicated family relationships, such as
blended families or estranged relatives, can make the process of creating a
will more challenging, leading some individuals to avoid it altogether.
4. Fear of discussing mortality: Some people may find it uncomfortable or
difficult to confront the idea of their own mortality, which can prevent
them from creating a will.

When someone dies without a valid will, the distribution of their estate is
determined by the laws of intestacy. The administrator of the estate, also
known as the personal representative, is typically appointed by the court.
The administrator is usually a close family member, such as a spouse or
adult child, but it can vary depending on the specific laws of the
jurisdiction and the circumstances of the case.

The court fees involved in obtaining a Grant of Probate or Letters of
Administration can vary depending on the jurisdiction. It is important to
note that I can provide general information, but specific details may vary
based on the country or state you are referring to.

In some jurisdictions, the court fees for obtaining a Grant of Probate or
Letters of Administration are fixed, while in others, they can be based on
the value of the estate. Here are a few examples:

1. Fixed Fees: Some jurisdictions have a fixed fee structure for obtaining
a Grant of Probate or Letters of Administration. This means that the fee
remains the same regardless of the size of the estate. For example, in the
United Kingdom, there is a standard fee for obtaining a Grant of Probate or
Letters of Administration, but different in Ireland.

2. Value-based Fees: In certain jurisdictions, the court fees for obtaining
a Grant of Probate or Letters of Administration are calculated based on the
value of the estate. This means that the larger the estate, the higher the
court fees. For instance, in some states in the United States, the court
fees may be a percentage of the estate’s value.

Your questions was broad so I have to response accordingly.

subject: Re: Dear Charles
body:
Thank you for sharing this information about the reasons why someone might not leave a valid will. It's interesting to consider the various factors that can contribute to this situation. Could you provide more details about the process of determining the personal representative of an estate when someone dies without a will? How does the court decide who is appointed in such cases?

Best wishes,
Charles

subject: I know what you know but let continue
body:
When someone dies without a will, it is known as dying intestate. In such
cases, the court follows a specific process to determine the personal
representative of the estate. Here are the general steps involved:

1. Petition for Appointment: An interested party, usually a family member
or close friend, files a petition with the probate court requesting to be
appointed as the personal representative of the estate. The interested
party is often a surviving spouse, adult child, or parent of the deceased.
2. Notice to Heirs: The court requires the interested party to provide
notice to all legal heirs of the deceased. This ensures that all potential
beneficiaries are aware of the proceedings and have an opportunity to
object or propose an alternative personal representative.
3. Background Check: The court may conduct a background check on the
interested party to ensure their suitability for the role. This check
typically involves searching for any criminal history or financial
irregularities.
4. Bond Requirement: In some cases, the court may require the personal
representative to post a bond. The bond acts as insurance to protect the
estate from any potential mismanagement or misconduct by the personal
representative.
5. Objections and Hearings: If any heir or interested party objects to the
appointment of the proposed personal representative, they can file an
objection with the court. This may lead to a hearing where the court will
consider the objections and make a decision.
6. Priority List: If multiple interested parties petition for appointment,
the court follows a priority list to determine who should be appointed. The
priority is usually given to the surviving spouse, followed by adult
children, parents, and other close relatives.
7. Appointment Order: Once the court reviews all relevant information,
considers any objections, and determines the most suitable person, they
issue an appointment order officially appointing the personal
representative.
8. Letters of Administration: After the appointment order is issued, the
personal representative receives “Letters of Administration.” These letters
serve as legal proof of their authority to act on behalf of the estate.

It is important to note that the specific process may vary depending on the
jurisdiction and local laws. Consulting with a probate attorney or seeking
legal advice is recommended to navigate the process effectively.

Note:
🎵

subject: Re: I know what you know but let continue
body:
Thank you for sharing this information about the process of handling an estate when someone dies without a will. It's interesting to learn about the steps involved and how the court determines who should be appointed as the personal representative. I appreciate your knowledge on this topic.

I have a few follow-up questions, if you don't mind. What happens if there are multiple interested parties who petition to be appointed as the personal representative? How does the court decide who should be given priority? And what role do Letters of Administration play in this process?

Again, thank you for sharing this valuable information. It's always helpful to understand these legal procedures better.

Best wishes,
Charles

subject: Re: I know what you know but let continue
body:
When there are multiple interested parties petitioning to be appointed as
the personal representative, the court follows a priority list to determine
who should be given priority. The specific order of priority may vary
depending on the jurisdiction, but generally, it follows a hierarchy based
on the relationship to the deceased. Here is a common priority list:

1. Surviving Spouse: The surviving spouse usually has the highest priority
for appointment as the personal representative. However, if there are
issues such as divorce proceedings or the spouse is unable or unwilling to
serve, their priority may be overridden.
2. Adult Children: If there is no surviving spouse or the spouse is unable
or unwilling to serve, adult children are typically next in line for
appointment. In cases where there are multiple adult children, they may be
appointed jointly or one may be chosen based on factors such as their
willingness, ability, and family dynamics.
3. Parents: If there are no surviving spouse or adult children, the parents
of the deceased may be considered for appointment. Generally, both parents
have equal priority, but the court may choose one over the other based on
various factors.
4. Siblings: If there are no surviving spouse, adult children, or parents,
siblings of the deceased may be considered for appointment. Like parents,
siblings may be appointed jointly or based on factors such as their
willingness, ability, and family dynamics.

If there are multiple interested parties within the same priority category,
the court will evaluate various factors to determine the most suitable
person. These factors may include their relationship with the deceased,
ability to manage the estate, availability, and any objections raised by
other interested parties.

As for Letters of Administration, they play a crucial role in the process
of administering the estate. Once the court appoints a personal
representative, they receive Letters of Administration, which are legal
documents issued by the court. These letters serve as proof of the personal
representative’s authority to act on behalf of the estate. The personal
representative may need to present these letters when dealing with
financial institutions, creditors, or other parties involved in the estate
administration process.
The Letters of Administration provide them with the legal authority to
handle the deceased person’s assets, pay debts, distribute assets to
beneficiaries, and perform other necessary tasks.

I am waiting for more questions rather than concentrating on our “deal”

Best wishes,
